Problem:
Consider the function \( z(t) = \int_0^t e^{(t-s)A} B u(s) ds \), representing the output of a linear time-invariant system with state-space matrices A and B, and input \( u(t) \). Let's explore how the introduction of a transformation \( f(z) = Ce^{Dt}z \), where C and D are constant matrices, affects the system.

Without any prior knowledge of whether \( f(z) \) was applied, can we recover the original input function \( u(t) \) from the observed output \( z(T) \)?
Explanation: The transformation \( f(z) = Ce^{Dt}z \) impacts the output in such a way that it could be fundamentally different from what would have been observed without its application. This variation introduced by \( f(z) \) compromises the straightforward retrieval of \( u(t) \) from \( z(T) \) without details of the intervening transformation.
